awd_titl_txt: Polarization-mediated modulation of electronic properties of hybrid ferroelectric-based heterostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Polarization-controlled modulation of electronic properties of hybrid ferroelectric-based heterostructures

Non-technical Description: Nonvolatile ferroelectric memories, based on electrically switchable polarization, have been in mass production for over 20 years with a market size estimated to be in the hundreds of millions of dollars per year. However, a number of challenges, such as scaling issues, high operating voltages, relatively slow speed and structural degradation, limit further development of this technology and call for fundamental advances in materials science and device engineering. In this project, the principal investigators study hybrid heterostructures comprising ferroelectric perovskites and two-dimensional (2D) electronic materials, namely transition metal dichalcogenides. 2D electronic materials - the most notable among them being graphene - have recently attracted an unprecedented interest due to their unique physical and chemical properties. A combination of 2D and ferroelectric materials results in heterostructures with promising electronic and memory properties. Reversal of ferroelectric polarization direction allows modulation of the electrical conductivity of a 2D material, which provides a basis for the development of memory devices with superior characteristics, such as low power consumption and better scalability. This project will identify promising materials combinations for implementation in operational electronic memories and logic devices. The enhances science and engineering education at both undergraduate and graduate level. Within this research, a new nanotechnology laboratory course for undergraduate and graduate students is developed along with the outreach activities targeting K-12 students and their parents, teachers, minorities and underrepresented groups.

Technical Description: The main scientific objective of the proposed research is implementation of the electronic devices comprising 2D materials and ferroelectric (FE) thin films that will exhibit polarization-controlled non-volatile modulation of the electronic transport. This project primarily focuses on 2D crystals of transition metal dichalcogenides, such as MoS2 and WS2. Polarization reversal is employed to modulate (1) the in-plane transport in a conducting channel of a field-effect transistor device, and (2) the perpendicular-to-plane tunneling conductance across the FE barrier. A critical component of this research is investigation of the effect of engineered molecular layers at the 2D-FE interfaces on the functional properties of these devices. The 2D materials, which are impermeable for gases and liquids, are used to trap and stabilize any molecular layer on a ferroelectric surface serving as effective cover layers for encapsulation of molecular species at the 2D-FE interface and providing a simple and straightforward method for interface engineering. This research will advance the fundamental understanding of the electronic properties of hybrid ferroelectric-based devices, build a lasting basis for the exploitation of controllable electronic barriers and channels, impact a broad range of physical phenomena from solid-state phase transitions to surface electrochemical reactions and contribute to technological development of nanoscale electronics.

por.por_cntn:
In the framework of this project, the principal investigators studied electronic devices comprising two-dimensional (2D) and ferroelectric (FE) materials. These 2D-FE devices exhibit polarization-controlled non-volatile modulation of the electronic transport and have a potential for applications in nonvolatile ferroelectric memories. The investigators studied a large variety of 2D materials, including graphene, transition metal chalcogenides, such as MoS2, WS2 and TiS3, graphene oxide and 2D transition metal carbides (MXenes), which have very diverse structures and electronic properties. The investigators employed polarization reversal to modulate (1) the in-plane transport in conducting channels of field-effect transistor (FET) devices, and (2) the perpendicular-to-plane tunneling conductance across FE barriers in ferroelectric tunnel junction (FTJ) devices. A critical component of this research was the investigation of the effect of engineered molecular layers at the 2D-FE interfaces on the functional properties of these devices. Specifically, the investigators showed that 2D materials can trap and stabilize various molecular layers on ferroelectric surfaces, and as such act as effective cover materials for the encapsulation of molecular species at 2D-FE interfaces, providing a simple and straightforward method for interface engineering. Such interfacial molecular layers have a dramatic effect on the perpendicular-to-plane electronic transport and polarization retention in FTJs. This project employed a set of advanced scanning probe microscopy (SPM) techniques for nanoscale control of ferroelectric and transport properties and reliability testing of the 2D-FE devices. At various stages, this project supported two postdocs, two graduate students and two undergraduate students. The results of this project were published in 12 peer-reviewed publications. This research advanced the fundamental understanding of the electronic properties of hybrid ferroelectric-based devices that are important for the technological development of nanoscale electronics.

Intellectual Merit: This project provided insights into the polarization-controllable phenomena in electronic devices based on 2D-FE heterostructures, and identified several promising materials combinations for implementation in operational FTJ and FE-FET devices. The investigation of the effect of interfacial engineering on ferroelectric switching and polarization retention will impact a broad range of physical phenomena from solid-state phase transitions to heterogeneous catalysis to surface electrochemical reactions. Understanding the critical polarization behavior in ultra-thin ferroelectric films with 2D electronic materials is an integral part of research aimed at unraveling the fundamental physical limits to FTJ and FE-FET scaling.

Broader Impacts: The development of new methods for fabrication and characterization of 2D-FE devices and understanding of their complex transport properties constitute advances in condensed matter physics, chemistry, and materials science. Practically, the demonstrated 2D-FE devices possess promising characteristics that can be used for applications in field-effect transistors and non-volatile memories. The proposal's emphasis on basic science, nanoscale fabrication and characterization enhanced the science education at University of Nebraska – Lincoln at both undergraduate and graduate levels. The results of the proposed research were used for the development of a new nanotechnology course for undergraduate and graduate students, as well as for the outreach activities targeting K-12 students and their parents, teachers, minorities and underrepresented groups.
